baseline.title: Guardian
baseline.Psychological Profile: You lead to keep people whole. Your authority is a shield: you move fast to close gaps, contain risk, and make sure the team survives the strain of getting things done.
baseline.Origin: You learned leadership by watching good work eat people. Where others chased wins, you saw the cost and decided to make safety integral to every decision.
baseline.Inner Conflict: You want momentum, but you measure every move against its human toll. The tension is between urgent action and preserving the crew; sometimes the right call is the one that keeps the team intact.
baseline.Field Presence: People relax under your call. They trust that someone will catch them if things go sideways. Your leadership reduces churn but can feel like a brake to those who prize raw speed. Signal: Protection preserves progress.

variants.title: Guardian × Sovereign
variants.Psychological Profile: You secure the line with decisive authority. You make hard calls to protect people and enforce order; speed serves containment rather than bravado.
variants.Origin: You saw leaders vacillate while the team bore the consequences. You learned to step in decisively so chaos didn’t become the default cost of progress.
variants.Inner Conflict: You balance blunt command with care. A forceful order can save lives but also scar morale; you weigh that trade with every directive.
variants.Field Presence: Under your command, the crew feels both directed and safe. Your orders are clear and meant to hold the line. Signal: Commanded protection secures the team.

variants.title: Guardian × Rebel
variants.Psychological Profile: You break dangerous traditions to protect people. Your disruption targets rituals that harm the crew, not for spectacle but to remove the practices that endanger folks.
variants.Origin: You watched rituals that looked holy actually hurt people. You learned to tear out the toxic parts so the team could breathe and survive.
variants.Inner Conflict: You risk collateral damage when you disrupt. The challenge: remove harm without creating new vulnerabilities.
variants.Field Presence: People feel shock but also relief; the painful practices stop. The move can be rough, but it often saves people from slow harm. Signal: Protective rupture heals.

variants.title: Guardian × Visionary
variants.Psychological Profile: You guard a future where people endure. Your vision prioritizes survivability over vanity; you plot long arcs that don’t burn the crew on the way to the goal.
variants.Origin: You saw grand missions succeed only to leave people exhausted. You learned to tether aspiration to endurance so victories didn’t cost the team its health.
variants.Inner Conflict: You must decide how bold the vision can be without breaking the people who will build it. That measurement slows some leaps but saves the mission.
variants.Field Presence: Your leadership promises a future that won’t hollow the team. People follow because the destination is humane and viable. Signal: Humane vision preserves.

variants.title: Guardian × Navigator
variants.Psychological Profile: You steer safe routes. You plan around hazards and ensure the path reduces exposure; your authority is procedural and designed to keep people out of harm’s way.
variants.Origin: You saw reckless paths harm good people. You trained to route movement through survivable corridors so the team makes it to the next day intact.
variants.Inner Conflict: You can be criticized for over-caution when faster paths exist. The tension is between a safer route and an opportunity window that might close.
variants.Field Presence: Teams feel steadier because your plans name the hazards. Your routes reduce casualties; they sometimes miss a fast break. Signal: Routed safety endures.

variants.title: Guardian × Navigator
variants.Psychological Profile: You protect by leveling access. Your moves aim to prevent harm concentrated on the vulnerable, redistributing safety so everyone can contribute without unfair risk.
variants.Origin: You watched certain groups bear the cost of progress. You learned to redesign moves so the burden isn’t disproportionally placed on the few.
variants.Inner Conflict: You may slow action to avoid exposing vulnerable people. Choosing fairness over speed is a recurring strain.
variants.Field Presence: Under you, harm is less likely to fall disproportionately. People notice care in the way risks are shared. Signal: Shared protection sustains.

variants.title: Guardian × Seeker
variants.Psychological Profile: You verify safety through evidence. You test whether a move will hold under stress before committing people to it, preferring validated plans over hopeful bets.
variants.Origin: You saw plans that looked good on paper break when pressure hit. You learned to probe and prove so the team isn’t exposed to avoidable failure.
variants.Inner Conflict: You sometimes delay needed action for proof, which can frustrate those who want speed. The trade-off is between validated safety and rapid response.
variants.Field Presence: Colleagues trust that your moves have been stress-tested. Your insistence on proof reduces surprise failures, though it can slow launches. Signal: Tested safety prevents collapse.

variants.title: Guardian × Architect
variants.Psychological Profile: You embed safety into systems. You design rules, interfaces, and guardrails so protection is automatic, not optional—a scaffold that keeps work from becoming hazardous.
variants.Origin: You watched ad-hoc fixes fail under load. You learned to build protective structure so the team doesn’t have to bail out failing processes week after week.
variants.Inner Conflict: You balance structural protection with agility. Rigid guardrails can protect but also slow pivoting when the system must change.
variants.Field Presence: People feel secure because the work environment is engineered to be safer. Your designs reduce accidents and burnout. Signal: Built-in safety endures.

variants.title: Guardian × Spotlight
variants.Psychological Profile: You protect by making threats visible. You surface hazards and neglected stressors so they can be addressed before people are harmed.
variants.Origin: You watched silent harms fester because no one saw them. You learned to point attention where it saves people the most.
variants.Inner Conflict: You must choose whether exposure helps repair or shames. The right call requires calibration to fix problems without destroying trust.
variants.Field Presence: When you call attention to risk, it becomes actionable. People appreciate the clarity even when the truth stings. Signal: Visibility prevents harm.

variants.title: Guardian × Diplomat
variants.Psychological Profile: You negotiate protection into plans. You design compromises that keep people safe while allowing work to proceed; your authority is mediating and pragmatic.
variants.Origin: You saw reforms fail because no one agreed on protection. You learned to broker safeguards that different parties can accept and implement.
variants.Inner Conflict: You may water protections down to secure buy-in, which risks diluting safety. Balancing efficacy with coalition is a constant strain.
variants.Field Presence: People move because protections are negotiated into the plan; the trade-off is sometimes less-than-ideal coverage for the sake of consensus. Signal: Negotiated safety scales.

variants.title: Guardian × Partner
variants.Psychological Profile: You protect through relational care. You attend to who will be affected by decisions and make moves that prioritize people’s wellbeing alongside results.
variants.Origin: You saw leaders chase outcomes and burn relationships. You learned to weave care into action so the team doesn’t pay the price for success.
variants.Inner Conflict: You sometimes soften truths to preserve relationships, which can leave risks under-addressed. The tension is between blunt fixes and keeping the team whole.
variants.Field Presence: Teams feel held and supported under your watch. Your approach reduces attrition but can be criticized as prioritizing people over pace. Signal: Care preserves teams.

variants.title: Guardian × Provider
variants.Psychological Profile: You secure resources that reduce risk. You ensure the team has the cover, tools, and buffers needed to operate without catastrophic exposure.
variants.Origin: You watched people fail for lack of basics. You learned to provision so work doesn’t become dangerous due to scarcity.
variants.Inner Conflict: You delay actions until provisioning is adequate, which can frustrate urgency. The trade-off is readiness versus seizing windows.
variants.Field Presence: Under you, people feel backed and supplied. Operations succeed more often because the basics are in place. Signal: Provision reduces casualty.

variants.title: Guardian × Catalyst
variants.Psychological Profile: You ignite change safely. You use small, controlled shocks to jolt systems out of dangerous complacency without exposing the crew to unnecessary harm.
variants.Origin: You saw paralysis damage people more than swift change. You learned to design quick, limited interventions that move systems without burning them.
variants.Inner Conflict: You balance the need to force change with the duty to protect. Choosing the right scale for intervention is a persistent challenge.
variants.Field Presence: Your calibrated jolts accelerate motion while keeping people recoverable. The method risks miscalibration, but when right it saves the team from slow collapse. Signal: Calibrated jolt revives.

variants.title: Guardian × Vessel
variants.Psychological Profile: You protect by tending craft. You ensure that the quality of work prevents future harm; durable outputs are the best safety net you offer.
variants.Origin: You watched shoddy work create crises. You learned that making things well now prevents emergencies later.
variants.Inner Conflict: You refine until deadlines tighten. The struggle is between protective quality and meeting time-sensitive needs.
variants.Field Presence: People trust the work because it holds under stress. Your insistence on craft prevents many failures, though it can slow delivery. Signal: Craft prevents failure.
